div1.head: Minutes of the Annual Meeting of the Board of Managers of the Walter Reed Memorial Association, November 21, 1946
div1.p:
Minutes of the
Annual Meeting of the Board of Managers of the Walter Reed Memorial
Association held at Washington, D.C., November 21, 1946

The Board met in the Board Room, American Security and Trust Company, 15th St.
and Pennsylvania Ave., N.W., at 10:30 A.M. and was called to order by its president,
Brig, Gen. Jefferson R. Kean.

Present; Brig. Gen. J. R. Kean, Maj. Gen. M. W. Ireland, Rear Adm. E. R. Stitt, Brig.
Gen. A. G. Love, Mr. Gilbert Grosvenor, Mrs. Hans W. Ireland, Dr. Philip S. Hench and
Col. J. F. Siler
Absent: Maj. Gen. C. R. Reynolds, Brig. Gen. F. R. Keefer and Dr. L. O. Howard.

Gen. Kean, in introducing the new member of the Board, Dr. Philip S. Hench of the
Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn., stated that the Board was particularly fortunate in
having Dr. Hench as a member, especially so because of his intense interest in and
knowledge of all matters pertaining to Walter Reed and his yellow fever investigations.
Gen. Kean stated that Dr. Hench became interested in the work of Walter Reed several
years ago since which he had devoted much energy and time to collecting all published
biographical data relating to Walter Reed and his work, in corresponding with and in-
terviewing friends and coworkers of Walter Reed and the men who served as experimental
subjects in the yellow fever investigations and in visiting the scene of the yellow
fever investigations in Cuba and securing first-hand information from all individuals
who had knowledge of the work. As a result of all these investigations Dr. Hench had
a much more comprehensive knowledge of Walter Reed and his work than any living Amer-
ican.
The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved.

div1.p: The report of the Treasurer was approved.

The following officers were elected for the forthcoming year:
President Brig. Gen, Jefferson R. Kean
Vice Pres Maj. Gen. M. W. Ireland
Secretary Col. Joseph F. Siler
Treasurer Mr. Hans W. Ireland

Gen Kean stated that occasionally individuals, connected indirectly with the
yellow fever experimental work in Cuba, were endeavoring, through special acts of Con-
gress, to have their names placed on the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor, notwithstanding
the fact that the type of service rendered by them in no wise justifies such recognition.
As such cases require investigations by the Medical Corps of the Army, General Kean
suggested that it would be desirable to elect the Surgeon General of the Army to the
Board of Managers and he asked the Secretary if this could be done at this time. The
Articles of Incorporation and By-laws were not available at the meeting but the Secretary
reviewed them immediately thereafter and found that the By-laws of the Association provide
for eleven members of the Board of Managers and that at the present time there are no
vacancies. However, these By-laws can be amended at special or annual meetings. If and
when the By-laws are amended to include the Surgeon General of the Army as a permanent
members of the Board, it should be understood that election would not be by name but rather
by position as the Surgeon General of the Army irrespective of the individual who might
be occupying the position.

Col. Siler brought up a question raised in a letter from Gen. Reynolds read at the
last annual meeting, namely, whether it might be desirable ar advisable to make concerted
efforts to secure material additions to the memorial fund. It was generally agreed that
it would be highly desirable to do so, particularly so if the income from the fund even-
tually is to be used for research. It was decided, however, that it would be unwise to
undertake any campaign for additional funds until final decision had been reached by the
Board of Managers as to the type of memorial eventually to be established. The matter
was therefore held in abeyance for consideration at the next or subsequent annual meetings.

Dr. Hench reported to the Board that as a result of his visits to Cuba he felt that
it would be highly desirable to purvhase the land and remaining sturctures at Camp Lazear
in Havana and convert the site into a permanent memorial in honor of both the Americans
and the Cubans who took part either directly or indirectly in the epoch-making yellow
fever investigations. A discussion of his plans and the progress made toward their accom-
plishment is summarized in Exhibit A attached to these minutes. Dr. Hench contemplates
raising funds for the establishment of this memorial through the solicitation of contri-
butions from a limited number of individuals, foundations and also commercial firms.

The members of the Board expressed their hearty approval of Dr. Hench's plans in
general and in particular his plan to make this memorial a dual one - Cuban and American-
and proffered their support and cooperation in any manner considered feasible by the Board.

There being no further business, the meeting adjourned to meet at the call of the
President.
